The second premise is "The bear was not in the cave", which can be symbolized as "¬B".

The conclusion is "The wolf was not in the den", which can be symbolized as "¬W".

The argument can be summarized as follows:
1. B → W (If B, then W)
2. ¬B (Not B)
3. Therefore, ¬W (Not W)

This form of argument is known as "denying the antecedent". In propositional logic, denying the antecedent is not a valid form of argument. The validity of a conditional statement (B → W) does not allow us to infer the negation of the consequent (¬W) simply because the antecedent (B) is false. The truth of the consequent (W) is not dependent solely on the truth of the antecedent (B); W could still be true for other reasons.

To illustrate this with an example: Consider the statement "If it is raining, then the ground is wet." If it is not raining, we cannot conclude that the ground is not wet, because there could be other reasons for the ground to be wet (e.g., someone watering the garden).
